subject: Re: [junit] TestCase classes and code
msgSnippet: So said  tumb@juno.com  on  12/14/2002 -------------------- ... JUnit.TestCase. ... I would rather let Kent do it. I cite
messageBody:
So said tumb@... on 12/14/2002 --------------------

>I suspect I'm not properly understanding what is meant by TestCase.
>You've got a definition that more than simply - extends
JUnit.TestCase.
>Could you define TestCase and comment on our testing system.

I would rather let Kent do it. I cite
http://www.xprogramming.com/testfram.htm. To paraphrase: a TestCase
class is a test fixture; a TestCase instance is an individual test
operating on the fixture.

>What we have a one to one correspondence of test classes to production
>classes. For example, a CalculatorEngine.java and
>CalculatorEngineTest.java (extended from TestCase) in parallel
>directories so that they're in the same package. When we we've written
a
>few tests and find that some setup code is repeated in more than one
test
>class (often because it's setting up a mock database or file system)
that
>goes into something we call a XxxxTestUtility class - maybe
>OracleTestUtility.java.

Why "Utility"? Is there no better name for what that class is doing?
Maybe you didn't know what it was until now. Still, "SetUp" would be a
better choice, don't you find?

>I'm wondering if our TestUtility is what you're calling a fixture even
>tho it doesn't extend TestCase. This class will setup the sometimes
>complicated objects, often instantiating several objects and setting
>their state. It's methods are then called by the test classes that
extend
>TestCase and are called in test suites.

You are right: your *Utility classes are test fixtures and you are
using TestCase to group tests together.

Your *Utility classes should be TestCase descendants and you should use
TestSuite to group tests together. If you do that, then you'll be using
JUnit the way it was intended. You seem to be going out of your way to
build something that JUnit gives you free of charge.

>We still have a one-to-one correspondence of test classes to
production
>classes which seems to help make sure that we test everything.

Justify this. I typically do not have a 1:1 correspondence. I cannot
see how having that correspondence (on its own) gives me any more or
less confidence in testing everything.

>And tells
>us where to look for code that tests a given class.

I admit that this is a nice consequence of the 1:1 correspondence.
Still, if the TestCase classes are named well, it will be clear. It's
not as though I split my tests into many test cases and those test
cases are named something Martian compared to the class name.

>If it matters, this
>project was started a few years before we'd heard of unit tests and
long
>before test driven development reached us.

Of course it matters. The world has learned since then. :)

To be clear, what you're doing is in no way wrong, except that you're
doing work on your own that JUnit does for you. The TestCase class is
designed to represent a fixture so that each test can communicate
simply with the fixture through instance-level attributes. By placing
the fixture in a collaborating object, you're simply making that
communication slightly more complex. If it works, then I won't argue,
but you're doing more than you need to.

Thanks for sharing your experience with us!
